1. Building and maintaining water infrastructure, such as dams, levees, and navigation channels, to reduce the risk of floods and provide reliable navigation of waterways.

2. Managing and protecting wetlands and other natural resources to maintain and improve water quality.

3. Regulating and issuing permits for activities that may impact water resources, such as dredging, construction in or near waterways, and oil and gas development.

4. Collaborating with local, state, and federal agencies, as well as stakeholders and the public, to develop and implement water management plans and policies that balance competing demands for water resources.

Certainly! One example of a project that the Corps of Engineers has undertaken in the past to manage water resources is the Mississippi River and Tributaries (MR&T) project. This project was initiated in response to the great flood of 1927, which caused widespread damage along the Mississippi River and its tributaries.

The MR&T project is a comprehensive flood control and navigation system that includes levees, floodways, and other infrastructure designed to reduce the risk of flooding and maintain reliable navigation of the Mississippi River. The project covers more than 2,500 miles of the river and the surrounding area, and it involves ongoing maintenance and upgrades to ensure that the infrastructure remains effective and reliable.

Over the years, the Corps of Engineers has also made significant investments in ecosystem restoration and other measures to improve water quality and protect natural resources within the Mississippi River basin. These efforts reflect the Corps' broader mission to balance the needs of multiple stakeholders and support sustainable water management practices.

The MR&T project is considered to be one of the most extensive and successful flood control programs in the United States. The project has significantly reduced the risk of flooding along the Mississippi River and its tributaries, particularly in the lower Mississippi River Valley.

The levees, floodways, and other infrastructure built under the project have made it possible to contain and channel floodwaters, thereby protecting lives and property from devastating floods. The MR&T project played a critical role in protecting the region during the historic flood of 2011, which was one of the largest and most prolonged floods on record along the Mississippi River.

In addition to its flood control benefits, the MR&T project also supports navigation and economic development along the river. The project has helped maintain a reliable and efficient transportation system that supports commerce and industry throughout the region.

Overall, while the MR&T project has been expensive, it has proven to be an effective investment in reducing the risk of flooding and supporting economic growth in the Mississippi River Basin.
